result.execSummary:
The defendant Robert J Beadle was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

2:02 Defendant Robert J Beadle in court with attorney Benjamin T Van Severen.  Nicholas Grode appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Attorney Van Severen states that defendant no longer wishes to plead today and requests matter be set for trial.
Court grants adjournment and matter set for trial. Any plea must be entered before 11:00 the day before trial.

and Witness List (Plaintiff)
Jury trial - 12 person at 10-21-2015 08:15 am
Defendant Robert J Beadle in court with attorney Wilhelm.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for September 25, 2015 at 09:00 am.
Pre-Trial Exhibit #1
WITNESS FEE - $16.40
Cover Letter (by Fax) from Atty. Benjamin T. Van Severen, dated July 24, 2015.

8:27 Defendant Robert J Beadle in court.  Sarah Kenas appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Court questions defendant regarding non-represntation. Defendant states he has retained Ben VanSeveren as counsel. Attorney VanSeveren does not appear. Court will proceed with preliminary hearing today.
Daniel Pelot is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Kenas. He is an officer with the Wisconsin Rapids Police Department. On 6/2/15, he was dispatched to a residence in the City of Wisconsin Rapids, Wood County. He made contact with W.B. and he identified individuals that were fighting in the roadway. W.B. had a cut on his arm and his shirt was ripped.
W.B. is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Kenas. The witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom. He states the defendant hit him with a baseball bat on 6/2/15. 
Attorney Kenas asks Court to take judicial notice of Milwaukee County case 15CF1880, a felony case the defendant was on bond for. Court takes judicial notice and marks document as exhibit #1.
Court finds probable cause that a felony was committed and the defendant committed it. Bound over for further proceedings. Bond is continued.
  Arraignment scheduled for August 10, 2015 at 09:00 am.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment at 07-27-2015 08:15 am
